articles.headline: Senate Votes to End Aid for Yemen Fight Over Khashoggi Killing and Saudis’ War Aims
articles.snippet: In a second show of bipartisan defiance against President Trump, the Senate also approved a resolution to hold Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman personally responsible for Jamal Khashoggi’s death.
articles.abstract: In a second show of bipartisan defiance against President Trump, the Senate also approved a resolution to hold Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman personally responsible for Jamal Khashoggi’s death.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Senate voted on Thursday to end American military assistance for Saudi Arabia’s war in Yemen in the strongest show of bipartisan defiance against President Trump’s defense of the kingdom over the killing of a dissident journalist.
articles.byline: By Julie Hirschfeld Davis and Eric Schmitt

articles.headline: How YouTube’s Year-in-Review ‘Rewind’ Video Set Off a Civil War
articles.snippet: To many YouTubers, the video felt like evidence that YouTube the company was snubbing YouTube the community.
articles.abstract: To many YouTubers, the video felt like evidence that YouTube the company was snubbing YouTube the community.
articles.lead_paragraph: You might guess that a surefire way to make a hit video on YouTube would be to gather a bunch of YouTube megastars, film them riffing on some of the year’s most popular YouTube themes and release it as a year-in-review spectacular.

articles.headline: Chase for Talent Pushes Tech Giants Far Beyond West Coast
articles.snippet: Amazon and Google are aggressively opening offices outside of their Silicon Valley and Seattle hometowns. On Thursday, Apple said it would invest $1 billion in Austin, Tex.
articles.abstract: Amazon and Google are aggressively opening offices outside of their Silicon Valley and Seattle hometowns. On Thursday, Apple said it would invest $1 billion in Austin, Tex.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — This generation’s biggest technology companies — including Apple, Amazon and Google — have long been tied to their hometowns. Now these giants are increasingly outgrowing their West Coast roots.
articles.byline: By Jack Nicas and Karen Weise

articles.headline: CBS Paid the Actress Eliza Dushku $9.5 Million to Settle Harassment Claims
articles.snippet: Ms. Dushku told investigators she was written off the hit series ‘Bull’ after enduring sexual harassment on the set. Lawyers scolded CBS for its ‘antiquated’ views.
articles.abstract: Ms. Dushku told investigators she was written off the hit series ‘Bull’ after enduring sexual harassment on the set. Lawyers scolded CBS for its ‘antiquated’ views.
articles.lead_paragraph: In March 2017, Eliza Dushku, an actress known for her work on “Buffy the Vampire Slayer,” signed on to play a major role in three episodes of the CBS prime-time drama “Bull,” and there were plans to make her a full-time cast member.
articles.byline: By Rachel Abrams and John Koblin

articles.headline: Trump Inaugural Fund and Super PAC Said to Be Scrutinized for Illegal Foreign Donations
articles.snippet: Federal prosecutors in New York and Washington are examining whether people from several Middle Eastern countries used straw donors to obscure donations to the funds.
articles.abstract: Federal prosecutors in New York and Washington are examining whether people from several Middle Eastern countries used straw donors to obscure donations to the funds.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Federal prosecutors are examining whether foreigners illegally funneled donations to President Trump’s inaugural committee and a pro-Trump super PAC in hopes of buying influence over American policy, according to people familiar with the inquiry.
articles.byline: By Sharon LaFraniere, Maggie Haberman and Adam Goldman

articles.headline: China’s Economy Slows Sharply, in Challenge for Xi Jinping
articles.snippet: Car sales are falling. Housing is slow. Workers get three-month unpaid vacations. For Chinese leaders, pressure for a trade deal with President Trump is rising.
articles.abstract: Car sales are falling. Housing is slow. Workers get three-month unpaid vacations. For Chinese leaders, pressure for a trade deal with President Trump is rising.
articles.lead_paragraph: DONGGUAN, China — China’s consumers and businesses are losing confidence. Car sales have plunged. The housing market is stumbling. Some factories are letting workers off for the big Lunar New Year holiday two months early.
articles.byline: By Keith Bradsher and Ailin Tang
